Authors: Cenggoro T.W., Aslamiah A.H., Yunanto A.
Title: Feature pyramid networks for crowd counting
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bioinformatics and Data Science Research Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Cenggoro, T.W., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia, Bioinformatics and Data Science Research Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Aslamiah, A.H., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Yunanto, A., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: In this paper, we propose the use of Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) for Crowd Counting problem. FPN previously has been used for retinanet, the state-of-the-art model for object detection. By using FPN, our proposed crowd counting model achieved a state-of-the-art performance for UCF CC 50 dataset with MAE 136.4 and MSE 223.6. The proposed model is also achieved a state-of-the-art MSE value of 7.6 for ShanghaiTech Part B dataset. The code can be accessed at https://github.com/wawancenggoro/fpncc. © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/) Peer-review under responsibility of the scientific committee of the 4th International Conference on Computer Science and Computational Intelligence 2019.
Author Keywords: Crowd Counting; Deep Learning; Feature Pyramid Networks; Scale-Aware
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Deep learning; Counting models; Counting problems; Crowd Counting; Feature pyramid; Scale-Aware; State of the art; State-of-the-art performance; Object detection
Funding Text 1: This research is funded by BINA Nusantara University Applied Research Grant 2019. Part of the experiment is run by using NVIDIA GTX Titan X from NVIDIA - BINUS AI R&D Center.

Title: Diminishing variant illumination factor in object recognition
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Yunanto, A., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kartowisastro, I.H., Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Undetected object(s) from a camera due to a poor condition of light intensity, or shadow that appears are problems that can occurs in object detection. This can lead to a loss, especially when applied in the industrial world. The purpose of this research is to fix an illumination factor, particularly the shadow factor on an image that will be detected by combining two methods, namely adaptive single scale retinex and shadow removal. Smoothing from retinex and shadow removal process are performed after an image is captured. Accuracy of object detection obtained is 95.45%, using experimental image detection program and random sampling method from 22 images of two datasets used in this study. Namely “Shadow Removal Online Dataset and Benchmark for Variable Scene Categories” and “Klik BCA” which obtained from the simulation process. This method can be applied to real time conditions, where the speed of the process is stable and fast enough such that it can be applied into industrial companies to help their quality control. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Index Keywords: Database systems; Lighting; Object detection; Object recognition; Adaptive single-scale retinex; Image detection; Industrial companies; Light intensity; Random sampling method; Scene categories; Shadow detections; Simulation process; Image processing

Authors: Girsang A.S., Yunanto A., Aslamiah A.H.
Title: A hybrid cuckoo search and K-means for clustering problem
Source title: ICECOS 2017 - Proceeding of 2017 International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Computer Science: Sustaining the Cultural Heritage Toward the Smart Environment for Better Future
Affiliations: Master in Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Girsang, A.S., Master in Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Yunanto, A., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Aslamiah, A.H., Master in Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Cuckoo search algorithm (CSA) is one of behavior algorithm which is effective to solve optimization problem including the clustering problem. Based on investigation, k-means is also effective to solve the clustering problem specially in fast convergence. This paper combines two algorithms, cuckoo search algorithm and k-means algorithm in clustering problem called FCSA. Cuckoo search is used to build the robust initialization, while K-means is used to accelerate by building the solutions. The result confirms that FCSA's computational time in ten datasets is faster than the compared algorithm. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Clustering; Cuckoo search algorithm (CSA); Fast algorithm; K-means algorithm
Index Keywords: Learning algorithms; Optimization; Problem solving; Clustering; Clustering problems; Computational time; Cuckoo search algorithms; Fast algorithms; Fast convergence; k-Means algorithm; Optimization problems; Clustering algorithms
